title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" permits the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act through a special message to Congress within 3 days of enactment. Once funds are made available for obligation, they cannot be proposed for rescission again under this Act or section 1012. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment by sending a special message to Congress. The special message must include a draft bill or joint resolution for each item of budget authority to be rescinded. The procedures for expedited consideration require the House to act within two days of receiving the message. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment by sending a special message to Congress. The majority leader or minority leader of the House must introduce the draft bill or joint resolution accompanying the special message, or any Member of that House may introduce it on the third day of continuous session after receiving the message. The bill or joint resolution introduced by a Member of the House must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it without substantive revision within seven days of receiving the special message. If the committee fails to do so, it will be automatically discharged from consideration. The committee must report the bill or joint resolution within seven days of receiving it, or it will be automatically discharged. A vote on final passage must occur within the 10th calendar day of continuous session after the bill's introduction. The bill or joint resolution must be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day it is agreed to. It will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven days, or it will be automatically discharged. A final vote must occur within the 10th calendar day of continuous session after the bill's introduction. The committee must report the bill or joint resolution without substantive revision within seven days of receiving it. Failure to do so will result in automatic discharge from consideration, and the bill will be placed on the appropriate calendar for final passage. The bill or joint resolution must be voted on within 10 days of being transmitted to the House. If passed, it will be returned for further processing. The House of Representatives must vote on the engrossed bill or joint resolution within 10 days of receiving it. A motion to proceed to consider the bill or joint resolution is highly privileged and not debatable, with a 4-hour debate limit divided equally between supporters and opponents. Amendments to the motion are not allowed, and reconsidering the vote is also prohibited. The House of Representatives must vote on the engrossed bill or joint resolution within 10 days. A motion to limit debate on the bill is not debatable, and appeals from decisions of the Chair shall be decided without debate. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section in the House of Representatives shall be governed by the House Rules. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to the consideration of a bill or joint resolution is privileged and not debatable, with no amendments allowed to the motion. Debate in the Senate on a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 10 hours, divided between the majority leader and minority leader. Debate on any debatable motion or appeal is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the manager of the bill. The Senate allows for limited debate on a bill or joint resolution, with time divided between the majority leader and minority leader. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration of any debatable motion or appeal. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable. Motion to recommit a bill or joint resolution is not allowed under this section. No amendments are permitted to bills or joint resolutions considered under this section in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. Any budget authority proposed for rescission must be made available for obligation. The text chunk explains that budget authority proposed for rescission must be made available for obligation the day after a bill or joint resolution is defeated in Congress. Definitions for "appropriation Act" and "continuity of a session of Congress" are also provided. The text chunk discusses how the days when either House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days are excluded in the calculation of continuous session periods. If a special message is transmitted during a Congress and the last session adjourns before 10 days of continuous session, the message is considered transmitted on the first day.
